This MimeMessage does not contain the selected part.
No file to import was selected.
The selected certificate is already imported.
The selected file was not an .eml-file.
Please enter the passphrase to unlock:
Sorry, something went wrong. Maybe wrong passphrase or invalid file?
No certificate was found for the recipient. Please import your certificate.
MimeMessage did not contain valid recipients.
The selected file does not contain a valid MimeMessage.
The selected file does not contain a valid decrypted MimeMessage.
An internal error occurred. Sorry for that. Please check the logfile.
An error occurred while extracting the certificate from the selected file.
Selected file has an unknown filetype.
Multiple certificate found, which should be used to decrypt message?
Who is the author of OpenSMIME?
Which other projects are used by this app?
How can I import my S/MIME-certificate from elsewhere?

First of all save your certificate somewhere on the phone. The certificate must be a file of type \"PKCS #12\" (ends with .p12 or .pfx). Then open this app and click on the Floating Action Button or navigate to \"Import S/MIME-Certificate\" in the sidebar. Use the opened file browser to select your certificate. Finally you have to enter your passphrase.
Will my passphrase be stored? Is this safe?

Yes, the app will save your passphrase, so you do not have to enter the passphrase each time you want something to be decrypted. Therefore a internal keypair is created and your passphrase is encrypted with this key. The encrypted passphrase will be stored in the internal storage of the application. Without being root no other app can even access the file with the encrypted passphrase and even with being root another app should not be able to get the private key to decrypt the passphrase because the keypair is stored in the AndroidKeyStore which should only be accessible by the app itself.
How can I import someone else\'s S/MIME-certificate?

Click on the Floating Action Button or navigate to \"Import S/MIME-Certificate\" in the sidebar. Use the opened file browser to select the certificate (.crt-file) which you want to import.\n It is also possible to import a certificate by clicking on the file in your file browser and selecting SMileCE in the list of \"Open with\".
How can I retrieve all information from the certificate?
Just tap on the card and the Activity, which shows you all kind of information about the certificate, will be started.
How can I delete a certificate?

Swipe the card from right to left will delete this certificate or open the popupmenue and select delete. You can also tap on the card to open the Activity which gives you additional information about the certificate and use the delete functionality in the toolbar.
What is the meaning of the coloured circles next to the certificates?
The colours are an easy way to see for how long the certificate will be valid:
What is the meaning of the coloured keys next to the certificates?
The keys indicate which parts are available:
How can I configure OpenSMIME to decrypt S/MIME encrypted mails?

First of all install K-9, OpenSMIME and import your certificate to SMileCE.\n Then open K-9 and navigate to \"Settings\", \"Account Settings", \"Cryptography\". Tap on \"S/MIME App\" and select \"OpenSMIME\". K-9 and OpenSMIME are now connected and your emails will be decrypted automatically.
If you delete this key, you won\'t be able to decrypt messages encrypted with this key.
Do you really want to export your certificate containing the private key to the SD-card?
Do you wish to share your private certificate with another app?
This is potentially dangerous. Others may use your certificate to read your email or worse sign their own mails with it.
Do you wish to share this certificate with another app?
Currently you have to pull %1$d %% to activate swipe.
Could not open key store for import
The given name was not recognised. Please try again.
The name contains forbidden characters (\'=\' or \',\'). Please change your name.
The given email was not recognised. Please try again.
The email contains forbidden characters (\'=\' or \',\'). Please change your email.
Your input does not seem to be an email address. Please enter an email address.
Passphrases do not match. Please reenter your password.
Failed to create certificate. Please try again.
The expert string contains errors. Please correct them or use default mode.
What is \"expert mode\" in Create Certificate?

You can use a formatted string to enter your certificate date.\nFor example: \"CN=Max Muster, E=max.muster@firm.org, O=Firm\".\nThis will set the name to Max Muster, the email address to \"max.muster@firm.org\" and the organisation to \"Firm\".
Started certificate creation. This may take a while.
